instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3209: What is 820-3209? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  <SIGNAL>P1V5CPU_EN</SIGNAL>  giving me 3.3v
threads.message:
Hi [TABLE]
[TR]
[TD="width: 550"] [/TD]
 		[/TR]
[/TABLE]


i have an old mac book air giving me 3.3v on <SIGNAL>P1V5CPU_EN</SIGNAL> I can see it is created from <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3_MEMRESET</SIGNAL> so i can see where it gets it from but i dont see how it is supposed to be reduced. could some one please help i am tired of looking at page 62 of the schematic and not ubderstanding. thank you..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  <SIGNAL>P1V5CPU_EN</SIGNAL>  giving me 3.3v
threads.message: That voltage is an ENABLE signal so 3.3 is fine. What is the problem with this board?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  <SIGNAL>P1V5CPU_EN</SIGNAL>  giving me 3.3v
threads.message:
"i dont see how it is supposed to be reduced."
Wrong assumption!!!
3.3V is correct, as above mentioned.
Pay aterntion to ENTIRE name and do not confuse power rails with signals...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  <SIGNAL>P1V5CPU_EN</SIGNAL>  giving me 3.3v
threads.message:
thank you for the replys
so green light going orange no fan spin
all power rails seem okay apart from
no <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>
so from <TRANSISTOR>Q7950</TRANSISTOR> I get
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> = 0.067V
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_SO_VMON</SIGNAL>=1.05V
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S3RSO_VMON</SIGNAL> = 0.27V
<SIGNAL>VMON_3V3_DIV</SIGNAL>=1.067V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_VMON</SIGNAL>=3.3V
???????

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  <SIGNAL>P1V5CPU_EN</SIGNAL>  giving me 3.3v
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S3RSO_VMON</SIGNAL> = 0.27V"
Check if 1V5 _S3 rail is OK.
As per schematic, VMON Q3 BASE should be higher than 0.65V...

However, you can remove <TRANSISTOR>Q7950</TRANSISTOR>; not needed for good working.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  <SIGNAL>P1V5CPU_EN</SIGNAL>  giving me 3.3v
threads.message:
sorry for not coming back sooner but lost half my roof in storm, 
your right <SIGNAL>1V5_S3</SIGNAL> not present tested short and it went to 0 ohms.  put 0.5v through the line at 6 amps nothing gets hot?? covered it in alcohol nada?  any ideas?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  <SIGNAL>P1V5CPU_EN</SIGNAL>  giving me 3.3v
threads.message:
If 5A limit bench power supply used, you are not injecting anything!
Start with lower voltage and increase it, maintaining ampers bellow limit.
Once 5A is reached, power supply gets blocked.
However such low voltage/power will not help you to heat anything.
You can remove CPU heatsink, but I doubt you'll detect something.

You can consider powerfull "injector"
[url]https://www.ebay.es/itm/AC220V-DC-0-5-12-24-48V-Adjustable-Switch-Power-Supply-Driver-Adapter-Led-Lights/332516815749?ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT&var=541593999842&_trksid=p2060353.m2749.l2649[/url]
If you can reach 1V/15A (as example), 15W should heat something there.

Removing <RESISTOR>R7350</RESISTOR> can help you to locate the short, <SIGNAL>1V5_S3</SIGNAL> power supply, or RAM/CPU.
